title: The Time Visitor
description: Anna is 70 years old and lives alone. When scientists invent a one-way time travel machine, she decides to travel back to 1975, when she was 25. She wants to fix her biggest regret - not telling her best friend David she loved him before he moved away. The story follows her journey back, her second chance at love, and the unexpected consequences of changing the past.

page1.paragraph1: Anna looked at her old hands. She was seventy years old now. Her apartment was quiet. Too quiet. She lived alone with her cat, Milo.
page1.paragraph2: The TV was on. A young woman in a white coat was talking about something exciting.
page1.paragraph3: "Scientists have created the first time travel machine!" the woman said. "People can now travel back in time. But there is one problem. They cannot come back to the present."
page1.paragraph4: Anna sat up. Time travel? Could this be real?
page1.paragraph5: The woman continued, "We are looking for volunteers. People who want to go back in time and stay there."
page1.paragraph6: Anna turned off the TV. Her heart was beating fast.
page1.paragraph7: "Milo," she said to her cat, "what if I could go back? What if I could see David again?"

page2.paragraph1: David. Just thinking about his name made Anna smile. He was her best friend when she was young. They met at university in 1975. They did everything together for two years.
page2.paragraph2: Anna picked up an old photo from her table. It showed a young woman with long brown hair standing next to a tall man. They were both laughing.
page2.paragraph4: But Anna never told David how she felt. She never told him that she loved him. Then one day, David told her he was moving to another country for a job.
page2.paragraph5: "I'll miss you, Anna," he said at the airport.
page2.paragraph6: Anna wanted to say, "Don't go. I love you." But she was afraid. So she just said, "I'll miss you too. Write to me."
page2.paragraph7: He wrote a few letters. Then the letters stopped. Anna never saw David again.

page3.paragraph1: The next morning, Anna called the number on the TV. A woman answered.
page3.paragraph2: "Hello, my name is Anna Wilson. I want to volunteer for the time travel program," Anna said.
page3.paragraph3: "Thank you for your interest, Ms. Wilson. How old are you?"
page3.paragraph5: "Perfect. We are looking for older volunteers. When do you want to go back to?"
page3.paragraph7: "And why do you want to go back to that time?" the woman asked.
page3.paragraph8: Anna closed her eyes. "To fix my biggest regret."

page4.paragraph1: Two weeks later, Anna was in a big white room. Scientists in white coats were walking around. There were computers and strange machines everywhere.
page4.paragraph2: A kind-looking man came to her. "Ms. Wilson? I'm Dr. Chen. I'll be helping you today."
page4.paragraph3: "Thank you," Anna said. Her hands were shaking a little.
page4.paragraph6: "That's normal. Now, remember what we discussed. When you go back, you will be in your 25-year-old body. But you will have all your current memories."
page4.paragraph8: "And you can never come back to 2025," Dr. Chen said seriously.
page4.paragraph9: "I know. There's nothing for me here anyway," Anna said. "I want to go back."

page5.paragraph1: Anna sat in a chair in the middle of the room. Dr. Chen put something like a helmet on her head.
page5.paragraph2: "Close your eyes and think about September 1975. Think about where you were then," he instructed.
page5.paragraph3: Anna closed her eyes. She thought about her small apartment near the university. She thought about the coffee shop where she studied. And she thought about David.
page5.paragraph4: "I'm starting the machine now," Dr. Chen said. "Good luck, Ms. Wilson."
page5.paragraph5: Anna heard a strange humming sound. Then she felt a pulling sensation, like she was falling.
page5.paragraph6: "David," she whispered. "I'm coming back to you."

page1.paragraph1: Anna woke up in a small bed. The room was small but cozy. Sunlight was coming through yellow curtains.
page1.paragraph2: "Where am I?" she said. Then she gasped. Her voice sounded different. Younger.
page1.paragraph3: She looked at her hands. They were smooth and young. Not the hands of a seventy-year-old woman.
page1.paragraph5: She got out of bed and ran to the mirror. A young woman with long brown hair looked back at her. She was wearing pajamas with flowers on them.
page1.paragraph6: "I'm twenty-five again," Anna said, touching her face. Tears filled her eyes. "I'm back in 1975."

page2.paragraph1: Anna looked around the room. It was her old apartment from university. Everything was exactly as she remembered.
page2.paragraph2: There was a calendar on the wall. The date was September 15, 1975.
page2.paragraph3: "September 15th," Anna said. "That means David is still here. He doesn't leave for another month."
page2.paragraph4: She opened her closet and looked at her clothes. They were all so young and colorful. So different from the clothes she wore as an old woman.
page2.paragraph5: "I need to find David," she said. "But first, I need to remember how to be twenty-five."
page2.paragraph6: Anna took a shower and got dressed. She chose a blue dress and brown boots. She brushed her long hair and put on a little makeup.
page2.paragraph7: "Now I'm ready," she said to her reflection. "Now I can find David."

page3.paragraph1: Anna walked to the university. Everything looked both familiar and strange. The buildings were the same, but they looked newer. And the people! Their clothes, their hair - everything was so 1970s.
page3.paragraph3: A young woman with curly blonde hair was waving at her. Anna stopped. Who was this? Then she remembered. "Susan," she said. "Susan Miller."
page3.paragraph4: Susan came up to her. "Where are you going? We have Professor Clark's class in ten minutes."
page3.paragraph5: Anna had forgotten about classes. She was a student again!
page3.paragraph6: "I was just... I was looking for David," Anna said.
page3.paragraph7: Susan made a face. "David? He's probably in the library. He's always studying. Come on, we'll be late for class."
page3.paragraph8: Anna followed Susan to a big building. They went into a classroom. Anna sat down, her heart beating fast. She was back in university. It was so strange.

page4.paragraph1: After class, Anna went to the library. She walked through the rows of books, looking for David.
page4.paragraph3: He was sitting at a table, reading a big book. His dark hair fell over his forehead. He was wearing a green sweater.
page4.paragraph4: Anna stood still, just looking at him. David. Her David. He was right there, just a few steps away.
page4.paragraph5: She had dreamed about this moment for forty-five years.
page4.paragraph6: David looked up and saw her. His face broke into a big smile. "Anna! Come sit with me."
page4.paragraph7: Anna walked to the table. Her legs felt weak. She sat down across from him.
page4.paragraph8: "Hi, David," she said. Her voice was shaking a little.
page4.paragraph9: "Are you okay?" David asked. "You look like you've seen a ghost."
page4.paragraph10: Anna smiled. "No, I'm fine. I'm just... really happy to see you."

page5.paragraph1: "You're happy to see me? We had coffee together yesterday," David said, looking confused.
page5.paragraph2: Anna realized she needed to be careful. She couldn't act too strange.
page5.paragraph3: "I know. I just... I had a strange dream last night. I dreamed you went away and I never saw you again."
page5.paragraph4: David put his hand on hers. "That's silly. I'm not going anywhere."
page5.paragraph5: But Anna knew the truth. In just a few weeks, David would tell her about his new job in another country. And he would leave.
page5.paragraph7: "David," she said. "Can we go somewhere and talk? I have something important to tell you."
page5.paragraph8: David looked surprised, but he nodded. "Sure. Let's go to our coffee shop."

page1.paragraph1: Their coffee shop was a small place near the campus. Anna and David used to spend hours there, talking and studying.
page1.paragraph2: They sat at their usual table by the window. The waitress, a friendly woman named Betty, came over.
page1.paragraph3: "The usual for you two?" she asked.
page1.paragraph4: "Yes, please," David said. "Black coffee for me and tea with milk for Anna."
page1.paragraph5: Anna smiled. David remembered how she liked her tea. These small details made her heart warm.
page1.paragraph6: When Betty left, David leaned forward. "So, what's this important thing you want to tell me?"
page1.paragraph7: Anna took a deep breath. This was the moment. She had waited forty-five years for this.

page2.paragraph1: "David," she began. "We've been friends for two years now."
page2.paragraph2: "Best friends," David corrected with a smile.
page2.paragraph3: "Yes, best friends," Anna agreed. "And that's important to me. You're important to me."
page2.paragraph4: David looked at her, his eyes curious. "You're important to me too, Anna."
page2.paragraph5: Betty brought their drinks. Anna took a sip of her tea. It tasted exactly as she remembered.
page2.paragraph6: "The thing is," Anna continued, "I feel more than friendship for you, David. I have for a long time."
page2.paragraph7: David's eyes widened. "What do you mean?"
page2.paragraph8: "I mean I love you," Anna said. "Not just as a friend. I'm in love with you."

page3.paragraph1: David didn't say anything for a moment. He just looked at her, his face surprised.
page3.paragraph2: Anna felt her heart sink. Maybe this was a mistake. Maybe he didn't feel the same way.
page3.paragraph3: "If you don't feel the same way, it's okay," she said quickly. "We can still be friends. I just wanted you to know."
page3.paragraph4: David shook his head. "No, Anna, you don't understand. I'm surprised because... well, I was planning to tell you the same thing."
page3.paragraph5: Now it was Anna's turn to be surprised. "You were?"
page3.paragraph6: David nodded. "Yes. I've been in love with you for months. But I was afraid to tell you. I didn't want to ruin our friendship if you didn't feel the same way."
page3.paragraph7: Tears filled Anna's eyes. "Really? You love me too?"
page3.paragraph8: "Of course I do," David said. "How could I not love you, Anna?"

page4.paragraph1: Anna couldn't believe it. David loved her. He had always loved her. All those years alone, all that regret... it had all been for nothing.
page4.paragraph2: "Why are you crying?" David asked, looking worried.
page4.paragraph4: David reached across the table and took her hand. "I wanted to tell you, but there's something else."
page4.paragraph5: Anna felt a cold fear. She knew what was coming. "What is it?"
page4.paragraph6: "I've been offered a job," David said. "It's a great opportunity. But it's in another country."
page4.paragraph7: And there it was. The job that would take him away from her.
page4.paragraph8: "When do you leave?" Anna asked, even though she already knew the answer.

page5.paragraph1: Anna nodded. This was exactly what happened before. But this time, things would be different.
page5.paragraph2: "I understand," she said. "It's a great opportunity for you."
page5.paragraph3: David looked sad. "I know. But now... now I don't want to go. Not if it means leaving you."
page5.paragraph4: Anna squeezed his hand. "Who says you have to leave me?"
page5.paragraph5: David looked confused. "What do you mean?"
page5.paragraph6: "I mean, what if I come with you?" Anna suggested.
page5.paragraph7: "You would do that?" David asked, his eyes hopeful. "You would leave everything here and come with me?"
page5.paragraph9: David's face broke into a huge smile. "Anna Wilson, you are amazing."
page5.paragraph10: Anna smiled back. "No, David. We are amazing. Together."

page1.paragraph1: The next few weeks were the happiest of Anna's life. She and David were together every day. They studied together, ate together, and made plans for their future.
page1.paragraph2: "We'll get a small apartment," David said. "Near my new office."
page1.paragraph3: "And I'll find a job too," Anna said. "Maybe in a school or a library."
page1.paragraph4: It was strange for Anna. She remembered a different life, a life where she and David were never together. But now, she was creating new memories.
page1.paragraph5: One evening, they were having dinner at Anna's apartment. Anna had cooked pasta, and they were sitting at her small table.
page1.paragraph6: "Anna," David said suddenly. "There's something I need to ask you."
page1.paragraph7: Anna looked up from her pasta. "What is it?"
page1.paragraph8: David reached into his pocket and took out a small box. Anna's heart almost stopped.
page1.paragraph9: "Anna Wilson," David said, opening the box to reveal a small ring. "Will you marry me?"

page2.paragraph1: Anna couldn't speak. In her first life, she had never married. She had dated a few men, but none of them were David. None of them made her happy.
page2.paragraph2: "Yes," she said, tears in her eyes. "Yes, David, I will marry you."
page2.paragraph3: David put the ring on her finger. It was a simple ring with a small stone, but to Anna, it was the most beautiful ring in the world.
page2.paragraph4: "I love you, Anna," David said, kissing her.
page2.paragraph5: "I love you too," Anna said. "More than you'll ever know."
page2.paragraph6: That night, after David left, Anna sat on her bed, looking at the ring. She was engaged to David. They were going to get married. They were going to have a life together.
page2.paragraph7: "I did it," she whispered. "I changed my past."

page3.paragraph1: But changing the past had consequences. Anna discovered this a few days later.
page3.paragraph2: She was in her apartment, going through her things, deciding what to take with her when they moved. She found an old photo album.
page3.paragraph3: The album had photos of her family. Her parents, her brother Tom, and her sister Kate.
page3.paragraph4: Anna flipped through the pages. There were photos of Christmas dinners, summer vacations, and birthday parties.
page3.paragraph5: Then she turned a page and gasped. There was a photo of her and a man she didn't recognize. They were both smiling, holding a baby.
page3.paragraph6: "Who is this?" Anna whispered, looking at the photo.
page3.paragraph7: And then, like a wave, new memories came to her. Memories of a life she hadn't lived yet.

page4.paragraph1: In these new memories, Anna saw herself getting married. But not to David. To a man named Michael.
page4.paragraph2: She saw herself having a baby, a little girl named Emily.
page4.paragraph3: She saw Emily growing up, going to school, graduating from university.
page4.paragraph4: Emily getting married, having children of her own.
page4.paragraph5: Anna as a grandmother, holding Emily's babies.
page4.paragraph6: "Emily," Anna whispered. "My daughter. But... I don't have a daughter."
page4.paragraph7: Anna was confused. These were memories of a future that hadn't happened yet. A future that now would never happen.
page4.paragraph8: Because she had changed the past. She had chosen David. And in that choice, she had erased Emily.

page5.paragraph1: Anna sat on her bed, the photo album in her lap. Tears ran down her face.
page5.paragraph3: The phone rang, startling her. Anna wiped her tears and answered it.
page5.paragraph5: "Anna? It's David. Are you okay? You sound like you've been crying."
page5.paragraph6: Anna tried to sound normal. "I'm fine. Just going through some old photos."
page5.paragraph7: "I miss you," David said. "Want to meet for coffee?"
page5.paragraph8: Anna looked down at the photo of Emily. "Actually, can you come over? There's something I need to tell you."

page4.paragraph1: That night, after Emily was asleep, Anna told David about the conversation.
page4.paragraph2: "Do you think she knows somehow?" David asked. "About where you came from?"
page4.paragraph3: Anna shook her head. "I don't think so. I think it's just a coincidence."
page4.paragraph4: "Or maybe it's something more," David suggested. "Maybe some part of her remembers. Some part of both Emilys."
page4.paragraph5: Anna liked this idea. That somewhere in her daughter was a memory of another life, another Emily.
page4.paragraph6: "Do you ever think about him?" David asked quietly. "Michael, Emily's father in your other life?"
page4.paragraph7: Anna thought for a moment. "Sometimes," she admitted. "He was a good man. Just not the right one for me. My heart always belonged to you, even when I didn't realize it."
page4.paragraph8: The years passed. Emily grew into a beautiful, intelligent young woman. She went to university to study science, just like her father.
page4.paragraph9: Anna and David grew older too. Anna sometimes thought about her first life, when she was old and alone. This life was so much better. So much fuller of love.

page5.paragraph1: On Anna's seventieth birthday, Emily came home with a surprise. She was now a scientist, working for a big research company.
page5.paragraph2: "Mom, Dad, I have something amazing to tell you," Emily said, her eyes bright with excitement.
page5.paragraph3: "What is it, sweetheart?" David asked. He was now sixty-eight, his hair gray but his smile still the same.
page5.paragraph4: "My team has made a breakthrough," Emily said. "We're developing something that could change everything."
page5.paragraph5: "What kind of breakthrough?" Anna asked, although she had a strange feeling she already knew the answer.
page5.paragraph6: "Time travel," Emily said. "We think it's possible. We're building a machine that could send someone back in time."
page5.paragraph7: Anna and David looked at each other. Anna felt a shiver run through her body.
page5.paragraph8: "There's just one problem," Emily continued. "It would be one-way. The person couldn't come back to the present."
page5.paragraph9: Anna smiled. "That's not always a problem, Emily. Sometimes going back is exactly what someone needs."
page5.paragraph10: Emily looked at her mother curiously. "That's an interesting way to think about it. Most people are upset about the one-way limitation."
page5.paragraph11: "Well, I'm not most people," Anna said, winking at David. "And neither are you, my brilliant daughter."
page5.paragraph12: "The theory came to me in a dream, actually," Emily said. "I dreamed about a woman traveling back in time to find someone she loved. It was so vivid, like a memory rather than a dream."

page6.paragraph1: Later that night, Anna stood on the balcony of their home, looking at the stars. David joined her, putting his arm around her.
page6.paragraph3: "I'm thinking about circles," Anna said. "How life moves in circles. Emily is creating the very machine that will send me back to find you."
page6.paragraph4: David nodded. "It's incredible. Do you think she'll succeed?"
page6.paragraph5: "She must," Anna said. "Or I wouldn't be here."
page6.paragraph6: They stood in silence for a moment, contemplating the strange twist of fate.
page6.paragraph7: "Do you ever regret it?" David asked. "Coming back? Changing everything?"
page6.paragraph8: Anna turned to look at him. His face was older now, lined with years of laughter and life. But his eyes were the same. The eyes she had loved for a lifetime.
page6.paragraph9: "Never," she said, kissing him softly. "Not for a single moment."
page6.paragraph10: And it was true. Anna had made a choice forty-five years ago. She had chosen love over regret. And that choice had given her a beautiful life, a wonderful daughter, and a love that transcended time itself.
page6.paragraph11: It was the best choice she had ever made.
